title: R. P. Keigwin
text:
Richard Prescott Keigwin ( ; 8 April 1883 – 26 November 1972) was an English academic. He also played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">Cambridge University</a>, the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a>, <a href="Essex%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Essex County Cricket Club</a> and <a href="Gloucestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Gloucestershire County Cricket Club</a>, and played <a href="Field%20hockey">hockey</a> for <a href="Essex">Essex</a> and <a href="England%20men%27s%20national%20field%20hockey%20team">England</a>.
Early life and education.
Keigwin was born in <a href="Lexden">Lexden</a> in <a href="Essex">Essex</a> and educated at <a href="Clifton%20College">Clifton College</a> (Watsons House) in <a href="Bristol">Bristol</a>.
He studied at <a href="Peterhouse%2C%20Cambridge">Peterhouse, Cambridge</a>, where he gained an <a href="MA%20%28Cantab%29">MA</a> in the Classics and Modern Languages <a href="Tripos">Tripos</a>. He was the editor of "<a href="Granta">The Granta</a>" in 1919.
Sporting achievements.
Whilst at Clifton, Keigwin partnered <a href="AEJ%20Collins">AEJ Collins</a> in the school <a href="Racquets%20%28sport%29">racquets</a> pair (he was also the school racquets captain) and he captained the school cricket XI for 1902-3 when Collins also played.
In March 1903 Keigwin was runner-up at the <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a>'s Freshmen's Lawn Tennis Tournament, losing in the final in two straight sets to future Wimbledon champion <a href="Tony%20Wilding">Tony Wilding</a> without winning a game.
In addition to playing for the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> at cricket, he also represented Cambridge University at cricket, rackets, <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> and hockey. He played hockey for <a href="Essex">Essex</a> and England, and cricket and <a href="tennis">tennis</a> for <a href="Gloucestershire">Gloucestershire</a>. He also played for the <a href="Free%20Foresters">Free Foresters</a> against the <a href="Netherlands%20cricket%20team">Netherlands</a> cricket XI in the 1920s, although he did not appear for Free Foresters at <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class</a> level.
After the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>, as a result of Keigwin's interest in Danish cricket, the game in <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a> picked up whilst he lived there and <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> cricket teams began visiting Denmark more frequently - these teams included the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> (MCC), <a href="Leicestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Leicestershire</a>, <a href="Incogniti%20Cricket%20Club">Incogniti</a>, Gentlemen of <a href="Worcestershire">Worcestershire</a> and Sir <a href="Julien%20Cahn">Julien Cahn</a>'s XI.
Keigwin's best bowling figures in first-class cricket were 8/79 against <a href="Sussex%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Sussex</a> in 1903.
A year later, he scored his only first-class hundred, for Cambridge against <a href="Warwickshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Warwickshire</a>.
His brothers, <a href="Herbert%20Keigwin">Herbert Keigwin</a> and <a href="Henry%20Keigwin">Henry Keigwin</a> both also played first-class cricket.
War service and honours.
In the first world war he was a Lieutenant in the <a href="Royal%20Naval%20Volunteer%20Reserve">Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve</a> serving on the <a href="battlecruiser">battlecruiser</a> <a href="HMS%20Indomitable%20%281907%29">HMS "Indomitable"</a> and stationed off the <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> coast. He was present at the surrender of the <a href="Germany">German</a> fleet. He was created a Chevalier of <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> <a href="Order%20of%20L%C3%A9opold">Order of Léopold</a>, Knight of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Dannebrog">Order of the Dannebrog</a> by HM King <a href="Christian%20X%20of%20Denmark">Christian X of Denmark</a> and awarded King Christian X's medal for "Valuable assistance rendered to Denmark during the war."
Published works.
Keigwin was a noted translator of <a href="Danish%20language">Danish</a> into <a href="English%20language">English</a>:
Keigwin also contributed to "Centenary Essays on Clifton College" (1962).
Occupation.
Keigwin taught modern languages at the <a href="Royal%20Naval%20College%2C%20Osborne">Royal Naval College, Osborne</a>, and taught at <a href="Clifton%20College">Clifton College</a> from 1919, as an assistant master (Master #246). He was House Tutor of Watson's House (his own old house) at Clifton College in 1919 and 1920, and was the Housemaster of Dakyns' House (Clifton College) from 1920 until 1935. Between 1935 and 1945, he was Warden of <a href="Wills%20Hall">Wills Hall</a> at <a href="University%20of%20Bristol">Bristol University</a>.
He was President of the <a href="Clifton%20College">Old Cliftonian Society</a> from 1957 to 1959, and a Governor of Clifton College.
He died at <a href="Polstead">Polstead</a> in <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a> and is buried in the churchyard of St Mary.
